questions.question_text:
You plan to deploy an SAP production landscape on Azure.

You need to recommend a solution to minimize latency between the application servers and the SAP HANA database server.

What should you include in the recommendation?

discussion.content: Correction answer should be A since the question is regarding latency and not traffic related.

Selected Answer: A
To minimize latency between the application servers and the SAP HANA database server in an SAP production landscape on Azure, you should:

A. Deploy the virtual machines to a proximity placement group.

A proximity placement group in Azure ensures that Azure virtual machines are physically located close to each other within the same datacenter. This reduces the network latency between these machines, which is crucial for high-performance scenarios like an SAP landscape where the application servers need to frequently communicate with the SAP HANA database server.
Option A should be more adequate since a proximity placement group will keep your servers close to each other and this takes effects on the latency.

choices.D: Deploy the virtual machines to the same subnet.
choices.B: Route all traffic between the virtual machines through an Azure Standard Load Balancer.
choices.C: Route all traffic between the virtual machines through load-balanced network virtual appliances (NVAs).
choices.A: Deploy the virtual machines to a proximity placement group.

discussion.content: Answer is correct , B is NO, because Set-AzVNAEMEExtension does not exist , exist Set-AzVMAEMExtension

You need to stop the SAP services so that you can perform monthly maintenance.

DRAG DROP
-

You have a single-instance SAP NetWeaver deployment hosted on Azure virtual machines that run Windows Server 2022.

You plan to implement Azure Monitor for SAP Solutions to monitor the application tier.

You need to ensure that Azure Monitor for SAP Solutions can access the SAPControl web service methods on the application tier. The solution must minimize application downtime.

Which three actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Proper solution:
 - From the SAP GUI, execute transaction RZ10.
 - From the SAP GUI, modify DEFAULT.PFL profile.
 - From SAP Management Console, restart the SAPStartSVR service.

questions.answer_description:
When you set up disaster recovery for on-premises VMware VMs, Site Recovery needs access to the vCenter Server/vSphere host so that the Site Recovery process server can automatically discover VMs, and fail them over as needed. By default the process server runs on the Site Recovery configuration server. Add an account for the configuration server to connect to the vCenter Server/vSphere host.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/site-recovery/vmware-azure-manage-vcenter

discussion.content:
You deploy an on-premises configuration server when you use Azure Site Recovery for disaster recovery of VMware VMs and physical servers to Azure. The configuration server coordinates communications between on-premises VMware and Azure. It also manages data replication. This article walks you through the steps needed to deploy the configuration server when you're replicating VMware VMs to Azure
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/site-recovery/vmware-azure-deploy-configuration-server
Shall we say given answer is correct? Any thoughts

choices.B: Microsoft System Center Virtual Machine Manager (VMM)
choices.A: an on-premises data gateway to vSphere

questions.question_text:
You have an on-premises SAP environment hosted on VMware vSphere.
You plan to migrate the environment to Azure by using Azure Site Recovery.
You need to prepare the environment to support Azure Site Recovery.
What should you deploy first?
